question_text:
Tyrone is sitting on a bench in the mall. He noticed that 2 out of the last 10 men who walked by had beards. What is the experimental probability that the next man to walk by will have a beard?

Write your answer as a fraction or whole number.

P(beard) = _
solution: The experimental probability is the number of times an event occurs out of the total number of trials.

Write the experimental probability as a fraction in simplest form.
P(beard) = $\frac{\text{beards}}{\text{total}}$
= $\frac{2}{10}$
= $\frac{1}{5}$
So,P(beard) = $\frac{1}{5}$.

question_text:
Beast is analyzing DNA samples in his laboratory. They noticed that 26 out of the last 78 samples containing the X-gene. What is the experimental probability that the next one will be a X-gene?

Write your answer as a fraction or whole number.

P(X-gene) = _
solution: The experimental probability is the number of times an event occurs out of the total number of trials.

Write the experimental probability as a fraction in simplest form.
P(X-gene) = $\frac{\text{X-genes}}{\text{total}}$
= $\frac{26}{78}$
= $\frac{1}{3}$
So, P(X-gene) = $\frac{1}{3}$.

solution: The experimental probability is the number of times an event occurs out of the total number of trials.

Write the experimental probability as a fraction in simplest form.
P(enchanted) = $\frac{\text{enchanteds}}{\text{total}}$
= $\frac{38}{150}$
= $\frac{19}{75}$
So, P(enchanted) = $\frac{19}{75}$.
